text:
1. INTERROGATORY QUESTIONING

What year did you start consuming in eastern Canada? 1912
Where did you go to housekeeping? Ontario
How far was it to your nearest store? 19 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Every week
That groceries did you usually buy in those stores?

any staple groceries

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand or white flour did you use in the early morning? White Bread
To what quantities did you buy? 100 lbs
Was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.34
How much did you use civilian flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour still locally? No
That was the price for a twenty pound bar of rolled oats? $7.50
That other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Whole wheat flour
Oats? Oats
Did you grind your own?
How did you grind it?
1. INTERVIEW QUESTION

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Carolina? 1914.

Where did you go to housekeeping? North Carolina.

Have you been living there before that? Yes.

For how many people did you require regular food?

How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles.

How often could a visit be made to the store? Every week.

Did you ever buy in town? No.

Any staple groceries?

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of wheat flour did you use in the early years? Wheat Bread.

In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs.

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of wheat flour? $2.83.

How much did you use each month? 50 lbs.

Was flour shipped locally? Yes.

That was the price for a twenty pound bag of wheat flour? $1.92.

What other grain products did you use? Oats.

How much did you buy? 50 lbs.

Did you grind your own wheat for personal use? No.

How did you grind it?
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy? (to nearest pound) $11.2
What was the price for a ten pound sack of this sugar? $1.44
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Best Foods
What size of tin or syrup did you use? 1 lb
At what price? $1.65

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? (county)
Butter? Churning
That was the price of butter? $2.00
Did you pack eggs for market? Yes
Did you make butter? Churning
What kind of cheese? Cheese

5. MEAT

What was your principal meat? Pork or Beef
How did you get fresh meat? Butchering & curing
How often did you get fresh meat? Monthly
How did you preserve meat? Salting & curing
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes
If so what year was it organized? 1916
Did you use game? No
For how long? 1916
What part did fish play in the family diet? None
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Canned
How many families? Johnson, Hammond, Andrews
3. **BEANS AND STAPLES**

In what quantity did you buy beans?  
What was the price per pound?  
What brand of canned corn syrup did you use?  
What size of tin or syrup did you use?  
At what price?

4. **DAIRY PRODUCTS**

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?  
Butter?  
That was the price of butter?  
Did you make eggs for butter?  
Did you make butter?  
What kind of cheese?

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

How did you get meat?  
How often did you get fresh meat?  
How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood?  
If so, what year was it organized?  
Did you use game?  
For how long?  
What part did fish play in the family diet?  
Was the flesh fresh, cured, or smoked?

Kindly...
6. Beverages:
   - What kind of tea did you buy? ... Black tea
   - At what price? ... $1.50
   - What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ... Ground
   - At what price? ... $3.50

7. Vegetables and dried fruits:
   - What was the price of potatoes per bushel, than you set up housekeeping? ... $2.50
   - Could you get potatoes at the store? ... Yes
   - If not, where from? ... [Handwritten]
   - What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
     - Potatoes ... 1912
     - Cabbage ... 1912
     - Turnips ... 1912
     - Beets ... 1912
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ... [Handwritten]
   - How did you buy prunes (in bulk or by the box)? ... [Handwritten]
   - What weight? ... [Handwritten]
   - How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ... [Handwritten]
   - What was the price of prunes? ... [Handwritten]
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apalaches, persimmons, panchas, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? ... All except Loganberries

8. Preserving:
   - In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning? ... Yes
   - What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ... 1912
   - What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ... 1912
   - Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ... Yes
   - To what extent? ... [Handwritten]
   - Did you make your own vinegar? ... No
6. NEW CROPS

What kind of tea did you buy? ... Red Band

What kind of coffee did you buy? ... Blend

At what price? ... $1.50

What kind of sugar did you buy? ... Brown

At what price? ... $3.50

7. VEGETABLES AND FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? ... $1.50

Could you get potatoes at the store? ... Yes

If not, where from? ... Home grown

That year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? ... 1912

Potatoes ... 1912

Carrots ... 1912

Onions ... 1912

Pumpkins ... 1912

Beets ... 1912

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ... Purchased

How did you buy prunes? (In bulk or by the box)? ... Box

That weight? ... 10 lbs.

Did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ... Yes

What was the price of prunes? ... $1.50

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apaltes, persimmons, pears, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In what crops did you make preserves? ... Apples

Pears ... Apples

Beans ... Beans

Sauerkraut ... Sauerkraut

Fruit by canning? ... 1912

Fruit by freezing? ... 1912

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ... 1912

What year did you first preserve fruit by freezing? ... 1912

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ... Yes

To what extent? ... All except vegetables made yearly

Did you ever make any fig preserves?

10. Baking:
- What type of yeast did you use? Only Royal
- Did you make yeast for your own use? No
- Using starters? No
- Salt rising? No
- Did you buy baking powder? Yes
- Did you take your own baking powder? No

10. **Baking**
   - What type of yeast did you use? **Dolly Royal**
   - Did you make yeast for your own use? **No**
   - Using starter? **No**
   - Yeast hops? **No**
   - Salt rising? **No**
   - Did you buy baking powder? **Yes**
   - Baking soda? **No**
   - Cream of tartar? **No**
   - Did you make your own baking powder? **No**

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, stream, dugout.)

If so, how was this water from your house?

How was it brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank)

For arid water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

Well
| Item Description | Quantity | Unit Price |
|------------------|----------|------------|
| Grilled Chicken   | 19 lbs   | $6.45      |
| Grilled Vegetables | 19 lbs   | $6.45      |
| Other Canned Goods | 19 lbs   | $6.45      |

**Water Supply**

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, cistern, dugout)

If so, how was this water from your house? (Well, barrel, tank)

How was it brought to the house? (Pull, hand pump)
13. SAMPLE
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? (If you made your own, did you use any kind of laundry soap or did you use something else?)

14. FUEL
That fuel did you use in the earliest days? (Give dates) Did you use any other fuel? (Give dates)

15. TYPES OF UTENSILS
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Did you use outdoor fireplaces or back ovens? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made? (Iron, copper, tin, homesteader)

What year was it purchased? (Give date)

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead)

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wood, steel, other)

When did you first use metal ware? (Give date)

Aluminum?
13. Did you buy January soap or make your own? 
   If you made your own, did you use lye? 
   Did Maude of Laundry help you? 

14. Fuel 
   Did you use coal, wood, oil, gas? 
   Did you use any unusual fuels? 
   Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, stating dates where possible.

Bottle gas or a coil in the parlor 
5 years 1945-6

3. Use of Gasoline or Oil Stoves 
   For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) 
   Did you use outdoor fireplaces or bake oven? (Give dates)

By how long was your first cook stove used? 
What year was it purchased? 
Price? $44.00

When did you first see an automatic (electric) range? 
When did you first see an automatic (electric) stove? 
Automatic?
In the booklet you will find two pages and one line written with red ink. It says:

"16. IMPROVING AND CULTIVATING

Potatoes and beans which you grow in the vegetable garden (or in the garden) are planted.

In the larger quantities and hard to be

up in larger quantities by the merchant lots

whipped and shipped by the smaller lots

to clay they are close in more accurate

and dense in water and more accurate

packages.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest

year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family

in their places at the table. Include the grandparents if living, the parents

and children.

My earliest year of memory was a small

my breakfast was much like this in my

household was very large. I was often to draw

from the stove to cook or wash dishes.

Dinner was cooked on the floor from dinner

cooked by my dear mother.

Dessert - Fruit - made by my dear mother

with applesauce and tea.

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

Give the name. List those present and give their

ages at that time.

That year I served my first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada.

Potatoes - Creamed Peas - Plum Pudding

Yummers Pie Nuts - Candy Cake - Matchless

My husband and I aged 25 - 30 - 21 years.

Myself

19. Have you ever refused to almost starve? If so, give details.

Locally grown foods? If so, give details."
16. **TRADITIONS AND CUSTOMS**

   In the earlier years, food was more plentiful and varied than it is today. Families would often have large quantities of meat and vegetables stored away in the cellar or root cellar. This allowed them to survive through the winter months.

   **17. FAMILY HISTORY**

   Give a brief history of your family. Include the names and ages of all members who have passed away. Also include any interesting stories or traditions that have been passed down through generations.

   **18. CHRISTMAS DINNER**

   What will you serve for your first Christmas dinner? List the main courses and side dishes.

   **Dinner Menu**
   - Roast Chicken
   - Mashed Potatoes
   - Creamed Peas
   - Plum Pudding
   - Minced Pie
   - Nuts and Coffee

   **Myself**
   Ages 25-30

   **19. LOCAL HISTORY**

   Have you ever visited a local historical site? If so, describe it briefly.

   **NO**
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Meals are fixed a lot fancier today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I always bought some prepared foods just to still grow and prepare my own food as much as possible.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

It wasn't so hard a life when I came to Western Canada so I haven't much to add. It wasn't as much pioneering as the years before.
I always try to buy fresh foods and prepare my own food as much as possible.

We weren't used to hard life when we came to Western Canada so I haven't much to add. It wasn't much pioneering on the prairie before.
March 20th

University of Rochester

May 10th

Archaeological Museum Office
